abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Structural Adjustment Credit
            Project will support the first stages of reforms,
            particularly policy reforms to improve governance in
            general, and improve public sector management, service
            delivery, and budget/expenditure planning. It will also
            provide foreign exchange to maintain essential imports,
            boost international reserves, and provide non-inflationary
            financing for the budget. The Government's cross
            cutting reform program to support private sector
            development, includes policy actions in the financial
            sector, privatization, and enterprise reforms, and reforms
            in the infrastructure sector. The project will be beneficial
            for the establishment of a government budget audit office,
            public administration, and customs reforms, and for
            improving fiscal management, and developing a medium term
            expenditure framework. Nonetheless, risks include the
            deterioration of regional security due to political reasons;
            as well as weak implementation capacity, suggested by the
            lack of government understanding of the need for
            implementing sustained reforms, a fact which may not be
            guaranteed. Additionally, restructuring of external debt
            with major creditors, may imply risks for fiscal, and
            external sector sustainability, aggravated by the low level
            of reserves, which could adversely impact foreign exchange
            management. However, it is expected that the assurance of a
            sound macroeconomic framework, supported by the Poverty
            Reduction and Growth Facility from the International
            Monetary Fund, will mitigate those risks.
